messages.subject: Re: new nihonto collector needs help with tsuba mei
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Gordon. I really appreciate the help. The kanji didn t show up on the post. Could you email me what you were able to come up with at
messages.messageBody:
Hi Gordon. I really appreciate the help.
The kanji didn't show up on the post. Could you email me what you were
able to come up with at mercierarmory@...?

Thanks!

Mike

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] new nihonto collector needs help with tsuba mei
messages.msgSnippet: Hi again, We are pretty sure the artist s name is Hideyuki $B1Q?o(B, but we cannot figure out the last character in the pseudonym. The first two characters
messages.messageBody:
Hi again,

We are pretty sure the artist's name is Hideyuki 英随, but we cannot figure out the
last character in the pseudonym. The first two characters are Ryû 竜 and jô 丈, but
we are not sure of the third character. It could be an abbreviation of "E" or 衛. I
checked Haynes as well, but no listing for this name. It is a fairly nice tsuba.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] new nihonto collector needs help with tsuba mei
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Mike, The entire inscription is the maker s name. There is no school name included. I am pretty sure the name is Hidemichi. The other three characters on
messages.messageBody:
Hi Mike,

The entire inscription is the maker's name. There is no school name included. I am
pretty sure the name is Hidemichi. The other three characters on the right side
begin with Ryû or dragon. The next two I cannot read. I have asked my wife to take
a look. I have check the Kinkô Dictionary and there is a listing for Hidemichi, but it
does not give his pseudonym. There are a couple of other possibilities for the
second character of the name. It looks like Michi, but it could also be Hideyuki
depending on the number of strokes in the character. Terunori is also a possiblilty
with the same characters as Hideyuki, just a different reading. Unfortunately, none
of these artists use the pseudonym shown on your tsuba.

Gordon

messages.subject: new nihonto collector needs help with tsuba mei
messages.msgSnippet: Hello everyone, new member here. My name is Mike and I was recently offered a couple japanese swords. I have been collecting swords for the past 10 years or
messages.messageBody:
Hello everyone, new member here. My name is Mike and I was
recently offered a couple japanese swords. I have been collecting
swords for the past 10 years or so, but primarily European. The one
is a WWII officer's with a mei on the blade of Ando Kanemoto. It is
in beautiful shape and I did not see any faults with it at all.
The other one has me a bit confused which is one reason I joined
the group. The blade is unsigned, but the tsuba does have a
signature. I have asked a lot of people, but no one is able to give
me a definate answer as to what it is. I assume the 2 sets of
characters is that of the smith and the school, but I don't know for
sure. Pictures of the tsuba and the tsuka can be found in the folder
I created at:

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/9ea7?c=

Like I hinted at, I am quite new to Japanese weaponry, and
translating kanji is certainly wayyyy out of my field. What I have
been able to come up with on the tsuba could be a few things. First,
the 2 charcters on the left (I don't know if everyone has the kanji
font on their computers but I will put it here anyways).

I see p for sure which I believe is either "teru" or "hide" the 2nd
character I have not determined for sure.

On the right side, I see either ³ (tatsu) or possibly `ê (taki)
followed by, I believe ä (don't know the pronounciation) and then q
(shi).

Obviously, what I want to know is who this tsuba is made by and the
school it is from. But also a potential date. I was informed by the
owner of the sword that it was authenticated by a friend of mine and
he thought it to be from the late 1600s or 1700s, but that is
certainly unclear.

Thank you all in advance for your help.

Mike
